Article.ArticleTitle: Chryseobacterium tagetis sp. nov., a plant growth promoting bacterium with an antimicrobial activity isolated from the roots of medicinal plant (Tagetes patula).

AbstractText: A novel plant growth-promoting and indole acetic acid (IAA) producing strain designated RG1<sup>T</sup> was isolated from the roots of Tagetes patula (marigold) collected from Goyang, South Korea. The cells of strain RG1<sup>T</sup> is aerobic, yellow, Gram-stain-negative, pleomorphic and non-motile. Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences revealed that strain RG1<sup>T</sup> belongs to the genus Chryseobacterium and is closely related to Chryseobacterium gwangjuense THG-A18<sup>T</sup> (98.6%). The strain produced IAA (70.5 µg ml<sup>-1</sup>) in the presence of <sub>L</sub>-tryptophan and showed antimicrobial activity against Gram-negative bacterium Xanthomonas campestris pv. campestris KACC 10377<sup>T</sup>. The isolate had a significant positive effect on rice plant shoot and root growth. The novel strain RG1<sup>T</sup> had a draft genome size of 4,430,189 bp, with ten scaffolds and 3969 protein-coding genes. The digital DNA-DNA hybridization (dDDH) and average nucleotide identity (ANI) values between strain RG1<sup>T</sup> and other closely related members ranged from 21.5 to 36.6% and from 79.2 to 86.6%, respectively. The genomic DNA G + C content was 34.8 mol%. Furthermore, anti-SMASH analysis of the whole genome revealed six putative biosynthetic gene clusters responsible for various secondary metabolites. The major respiratory quinone was MK-6 and the major fatty acids were iso-C<sub>15:0</sub>, summed feature 3 (comprising C<sub>16: 1</sub>ω7c and/or C<sub>16: 1</sub>ω6c) and summed feature 9 (comprising iso-C<sub>17: 1</sub> ω9c and/or 10-methyl C<sub>16:0</sub>). The major polar lipid is phosphatidylethanolamine. Based on the genotypic, chemotaxonomic and physiological data, strain RG1<sup>T</sup> represents a novel species, for which the name Chryseobacterium tagetis sp. nov. is proposed. The type strain is designated as RG1<sup>T</sup> ( = KCTC 82696<sup>T</sup> = NBRC 115057<sup>T</sup>).
